text: I am Sandra Finley and I am president
and CEO of League of black women what we
do at League of black women is
leadership research and education
programs based on that research and
we're specifically looking at how black
women Advance against their own
Ambitions now in in taking that on it
means that we don't do a lot of the kind
of work that other organizations do
primarily because they do it so we don't
spend a lot of time comparing black
women to white
women uh we don't spend a lot of time
looking at the differences between the
gap of black women's achievement and um
white women's achievement and that sort
of thing we don't even spend a lot of
time looking at black women's Ambitions
against what white men do we look at
what black women say they want to do and
we look at the prospects for them being
able to achieve those Ambitions and we
also particularly interested and how far
out black women are willing to go in
order to dream about what the potential
for their Ambitions are likely to be and
and that is what we do and so what I
wanted to add to this discussion here
was a a view that you don't normally
have access to so in order to do that
I'm going to issue from the authority of
me provisional visas for all of you all
who don't think you are black women to
walk with me into black world
okay you got a Visa so you can be here
with no apologies nobody asking you to
pat you down and wonder what are you
doing here you're with
me and for the black women who are here
this is home coming for a little while
and for the brothers well y'all know
where we
are along with it so we're going to
spend a little time from this
perspective so that we can get to some
of the points of interest that might not
normally be available to you in uh
discussions that you might have
Gatherings of this
type and I also want to thank some of
the folk who brought me here three in
particular I want to thank Robin because
uh Robin and I met as she said at a at a
conference that she was U our
facilitator for and she was very kind
and that she kind of let me have some
time and actually helped me be really
good at what I was doing that day so I
want to thank you
Robin I also want to thank Robert
Livingston who is sitting here because
he helped Advance the league of black
women's leadership research and he's got
a piece of work that's still hanging out
there and we are waiting like people
wait for the great sale at Macy's you
know for it to be done so we can get the
results I want to thank him very much
for that and then I also want to give a
gift because I think you should appear
at the table with more than your knife
and fork and I want to give you Kim
vappy who is a colleague of the league
of black women and my gift to you is
sometime with Kim as she is visiting
back and forth and assigned by Robin at
your various tables because Kim is the
CEO of a company a great company called
minty
and so for some of those of you who are
trying to figure out how you're going to
actually structure the diversity that
you seek you want the expertise of mum
to help you figure out how to do that
and Kim is that
instrument what I wanted to do was talk
to you a little bit about now that we
are in black woman world together for a
little while uh a perspective on the
experience and as reflected in the
results of our research in 2011 League
of black women conducted a a research
survey that we called risk and reward
and it's in your packets risk and reward
looked at what the Gap might be between
a black woman's experience and her own
goals for herself to help explain some
of our what you call behaviors
particularly corporate experience where
we look at how black women make a
decision to move from one company to the
other what were we seeking what was it
that urged us out or what is it that U
might have made it so that we could have
stayed and matured and so we call that
experience looking at the risk and the
reward of it and in getting ready to do
that try to think about it differently I
had to think about my own experience
just in the world on any given day just
getting to you here flying to Boston I
had the experience that it's pretty much
getting to be typical for me on an
airplane I sit and I open up my stuff
and it's heavily branded League of black
women so typically whoever is sitting
next to me will go oh what is that
League of black women and so I briefly
say what we do and then they always ask
me to explain black women in some way or
another you know it the question comes I
have a friend or we had someone who
worked for us who left or why don't
black women or blah whatever it is maybe
one of the toughest ones was when
somebody asked me on one of those trips
uh to explain the whiteness in my
apparent
skin so here's what that looked like
well obviously you must have some white
people in your family
because you were like and she didn't say
the word but she wanted to say
light along with it and and so what I'm
going to say to you is on any given day
here in Black world or black women world
you never are quite sure how the day is
going to
go and at any given time in any
different moment somebody takes
something like a psychological stick and
feels fully authorized to poke you with
it and and have you explain yourself or
explain your people or whatever it is
that they choose to do
you never quite get okay it's like being
permanently locked in the loop at TSA at
the airport where people Pat you at any
given time and so we live in this state
of of kind of unease a disease about the
disease of not being fully credential
authoritative members safely in this
society and with all of that we still
are I think quite remarkable people I
want to talk to you a little bit about
the findings the summary of key findings
of this report and then get
to the thing I know Robin wants me to
do the summary of the key findings we
looked at risk-taking simply to
determine if the return on the
investment that we make in this Society
advancing was worth what it is that we
put into it whether you want to
characterize it as joining the feminist
movement buying a house in a community
that is particularly upscale making a
decision to come to Harvard to access
the best of the best of whatever we
think education might be and we found
out that black women on their own lack
sponsorship for risk-taking at work for
career
advancement and what's interesting about
that is we kind of always knew it but
lately we know absolutely what the kiss
of death is of not having sponsorship
and having invested quite a lot in the
advancement of a career that absolutely
requires it so we live in a time where
we don't have access to sponsorship that
is people who will pull you pull you and
let go of this illusion of you
bootstrapping and lifting Yourself by
your own bootstraps but do what
sponsorship always does is pull and
protect you along the way but we're just
the assumption is that we're just going
to make it happen but we lack access to
sponsorship and so the likelihood we're
able to tell women because of this
research is that that trail that path
you want to go even if you as an
individual make it it's highly unlikely
that your daughters will be able to on
mass it's highly unlikely that you'll be
able to bring your community to the
success that youve achieved and you will
be what Malcolm Gladwell caus the
outlier for a very long time and is that
the Fate you choose if not we have to do
some things differently we found out
that black women were primarily
self-motivated to do the things that
they do and have the success that they
have and this was particularly
problematic because we thought that our
strength as strong black women we make
it so being selfmotivated I will do it
myself a good thing what's wrong with
being a strong black woman and we found
out that other
communities would have other parts of
their local their their their larger
Community supporting their success but
we were out there being by ourselves and
considering trying to make that some
sort of normal experience and it was
making us sick and tired and not well we
don't sleep at night our minds just
rised
our stomach's hurt and we have stress
which counts to other things as well and
it's not because we're weak but it is
because we are in this Perpetual
Frontline position that never changes
even geese that fly in formation change
the goose in the front from time to
time they tell me that the Roman
soldiers who fought in that particular
box kind of confirmation had exactly six
month I mean six minutes on the front
that you had to hold your Shield and
thrust like this doing the exact same
thing that the Roman to the left and the
right of you did and at the end of six
minutes you move to the side and go to
the back and you weren't up again for
maybe another 40
minutes but black women stay on the
front line self-motivated self-propelled
to try to make it happen not because we
don't choose to shift to the second
position but because there is no backup
for us we looked at something called
weaker and less strategic networks we
found out that black women lack access
to powerful and trusted advisors who can
provide strategic and informed councel
on how to evaluate the risk an
opportunity and that's been talked about
earlier today so I won't spend much more
time on it except to say you know it's
really
important let me tell you that we were
now interested after we got this
information in understanding why this
set of circumstances keeps happening and
happening and happening generation after
generation yet we keep getting asked to
this particular dance
we heard earlier today Paula talked
about oh Elizabeth Katie
Stanton Susan banthony the same
invitation to Black women come let's
March together for more rights for women
and so we do I do it this way remember
you're with me now so we March side by
side arms linked sister to sister
Marching for the rights for improvement
whether it's voting or health care you
name it whatever it might be we all
gather we are called to the rally and we
March just like that and we March to the
door of power and we knock on that door
all of us together Bam Bam Bam let us in
we want
change and power opens the door and
power opens the door and looks at us and
says all right all right we know there's
got to be some
change send someone in and we'll sit
down and talk about it but then what
power does instead of letting us choose
who we send in or how we send in power
chooses who it invites in and it always
invites my sister not my
sister my sister is invited not my
sister but my sister says don't worry
we've been marching together I got
this you know I got this don't worry
about it and she goes in and she sits at
the table and starts to negotiate and it
says look I get it there's going to have
to be change and there's going to be
change in fact I'm going to offer you
this this this and this and that can
change but we can't handle a race thing
right
now and then my sister sees closer than
she's ever seen before these core
elements of whatever the campaign is
about and it's right there in her hand
she can feel it taste it smell it but
that race thing and then she makes a
calculated decision and she takes the
deal and she comes out and she tells all
of us including me and you two we got
this this this and this but we didn't
get that race thing but don't you worry
we're going to come back for
that and what we now know is no one ever
comes back that's not what movements do
they go forward they never go back what
they don't settle in the campaign
forward ever never never gets settled
until the next campaign for that
particular issue if that happens and
sometimes it never
does and so the league of black women
looks at this behaving you and we look
at the Loop it keeps happening for
Elizabeth it happens again over the ages
and even in modern
times and we wonder what happened did my
sister Punk
at the
table and then we afforded our
opportunities to play the tape over and
over and over again to see what you
don't normally see and we found out
something that's of news to you right
now if you are thinking about inventing
the world
again that my
sister did not Punk at the table that
the Trap wasn't sprung at the table the
Trap was sprung at the
door
when she came into the room alone to
represent all of us the rest of it was
the feta
complete I want you to let that sit with
you a little bit all of you who sitting
on committees representing all the
women heads of departments dean of this
and head of that representing the
interest of all of the women because
your heart is Right thinking about what
you're going to do about diversity you
have to consider if you sit at that
table by yourself presuming to represent
my needs and my interest trap is already
sprung it cannot and will not get done
and you will have to come out and tell
me about your disappointment of my
situation again and again and again so
League of black women ask the question
what to be done about this we need to
give better advice to our sisters and to
our sisters about this invitation to
this particular dance over and over
again and we have determined for action
and change this ought to be our response
when power makes that invitation
again it will make the invitation over
and over again to
Sister it will invite Gloria dyam and
not Angela
Davis it will do that but what Gloria
must say what sister must say at that
invitation is Not Without my
Sister you don't go in there alone you
don't let power divide you there is
nothing good that will come of it that
will be of the benefit that we all
sought if you do that so we wanted you
to know about where the Trap is sprung
so you say not without my sister that's
what you must say and to my
sisters going in we have to say that we
require that our sisters carry their
share of the
weight of what the movement must
ultimately imp fully be evolved into in
order to be the youth that we want it to
be going
forward it means that they can't just
get so far and determine we've gone far
enough it's getting difficult
now we should do is be kind of good with
what we've got and then come back
another time when times are better we
must tell sister that when she
sits she becomes part of the weight and
so we have to keep her on her feet
and moving forward and challenge her to
do that sort of thing there's a poem
called instill our rise and it's for
those of you who've heard it it is a
series of challenges and then the
narrator says even in the face of those
things instill our rise so we have to as
sisters tell our sisters when she sits
down she's in the middle of a poem call
and still I
sit she got to get
up and keep going for the word world
that she says that she wants and the
life that she says that she wants to be
a part of she must keep going so that we
go together through this whole thing I
want to say in my last few minutes
something about the language that we use
to describe our Ambitions and our goal
we're talking about bridge building here
but we need to be very careful as to
where we think those bridges are going
to be built towards and to some of these
Bridges don't need to be
built we don't need to build a bridge to
something called a postracial
Society because the the tax that we have
to pay to be members of that is more
than we want to
Bear there is a difference between race
and
racist and we must be careful to use the
right terms for the right situation we
don't need to be post- red it's a
beautiful thing my race
yours the racist behavior is something
that we don't want amongst us we have to
tax it first and then get rid of it we
also want to get rid of some caricatures
so we don't ever have to face them again
and again and again each generation I
want to have a great funeral here in
Black world and invite all of you to
come it's going to be big it's going to
be New Orleans style we're going to dig
some holes deep in the ground and we
going to bury some caricatures we're
going to bury nice lady 6 feet
deep nice lady lies here she dead head
we no longer have to be concerned about
her
behavior she didn't live anymore we
don't have to be mimicking her behaviors
or anything like that we're going to
bury angry black
woman 14 15 feet
deep all right she never lived we don't
have to be concerned about her
anymore we're going to be the list goes
on of who's going to be at this funeral
that we bury but once we buried we won't
have any grieving or anything like that
cuz we have to remember she never was us
anyway she was invented and when she
brings herself on into the room to
confuse us and to stress us out and get
us all suspicious of each other we have
to remember didn't she
die and if she has not the good Grace To
Die ladies let us kill
her Malcolm gladwell's a new book called
David and Goliath first chapter tells
the story of David and Goliath that we
all like and know and then he says if we
understand David and Goliath the way
that the story normally goes then we
don't understand anything about what
really went down between David and
Goliath he simply says we like the story
of David and Goliath because we relate
to David because he was the underdog and
we like the story of a good Underdog
Don't We rise against all but he says
David never was the underdog because
David was artillery and Goliath was
infantry and artillery always always
always be
infantry so the other myth that we have
to bury is that we are The
Underdogs we are not we are like David
we are agile we are unexpected and we
have unique
Firepower he also tells us that there's
a part of the story that's rarely told
that finishes off the fa the story and
that is after Goliath falls down from
David's Rock David jumps on his chest
takes his knife out and cuts his head
off make sure he's good and
dead and I want for us to improve our
end games so that when we make campaigns
and we make for improvement and we give
everything that we've got to it that we
remember to cut his head off so it
doesn't rise and come back and bother
another generation of our sisters and
our sisters I hope you've enjoyed your
visit into black World your visas will
expire the end of the
day and for the sisters who came home
come home more often it feels good in
here thank
you
